case_title: M/S. Kaghan Ghee Mills (Pvt.) Limited vs Collector Of Customs and Other

accussed_details.name: Messrs Kaghan Ghee Mills (Pvt.) Limited
allegation: Illegal removal of RBD palm oil from bonded warehouse without payment of duties and taxes

complaint_summary: The appellant was accused of unlawfully removing 230.525 tonnes of RBD palm oil from a bonded warehouse without paying customs duties and taxes.
investigation_summary: The Superintendent of Customs and Central Excise found discrepancies in the bonded warehouse stock. The General Manager of the appellant admitted to the removal of goods without payment of duties and taxes.
judgment_summary: The court held that the appellant was liable under section 156(1) clause 62 of the Customs Act, 1969, which imposes a maximum penalty of Rs. 25,000. The previous penalty of Rs. 5,00,000 imposed by the Appellate Tribunal was set aside.
punishment: Maximum penalty of Rs. 25,000 under section 156(1) clause 62 of the Customs Act, 1969.
Decision_or_verdict: Appeal allowed; penalty reduced to Rs. 25,000.
legal_arguments: Appellant argued that clause 62 of section 156(1) of the Customs Act, 1969 was applicable, limiting the penalty to Rs. 25,000.
Respondent argued that clause 90 of section 156(1) was applicable, allowing a penalty up to ten times the value of the goods.
statutes: Constitution of the Islamic Republic of Pakistan, 1973
sections: Articles 4 and 25 of the Constitution of Pakistan
witnesses: General Manager of Messrs Kaghan Ghee Mills (Pvt.) Limited

witness_statement.General Manager: Admitted removal of 230.525 tonnes of RBD palm oil from the bonded warehouse without payment of duties and taxes.

key_issues: Applicability of section 156(1) clause 62 versus clause 90 of the Customs Act, 1969
Penalty assessment for illegal removal of goods from bonded warehouse

maxims.Ultra vires: Penalty exceeding statutory limits is unlawful.

legal_terms.Bonded warehouse: A secured facility where imported goods are stored without payment of duties until cleared.

words_and_phrases.Clandestine removal: Secretive or unauthorized removal of goods.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the illegal removal of goods from a bonded warehouse by the appellant without payment of duties and taxes. The court determined that the penalty should be limited to Rs. 25,000 under section 156(1) clause 62 of the Customs Act, 1969, setting aside the previous penalty of Rs. 5,00,000 imposed by the Appellate Tribunal.
